title: Mount Targon: Explore the Mountain and it's five resident champions!

embed.description: Like any place of myth, Mount Targon is a beacon to dreamers, madmen and questors of adventure. Those who survive the arduous journey to the foot of the titanic mountain find a sky shimmering with celestial bodies; the sun and moons, but also constellations, planets, fiery comets that streak the darkness, and auspicious arrangements of stars.

body: It's here folks! Explore the wonders of Mount Targon first hand!

Really like them, especially the new Pantheon lore.

Also, please remember to keep your characters vulnerable when writing. Pantheon, being the avatar of an aspect of war, makes sense as a nigh invulnerable paragon. However, in the harrowing story, reading about Miss Fortune, Lucian and Olaf miraculously dodging every bullet and sword swung at them while killing three ghosts with one bullet felt silly and forced.
Olaf doesn't dodge, he just endures.

I feel like Diana new lore is mostly unchanged, just fleshed out in a good way, so nice job on that.

I never had any special attachment to Pantheon, so no strong feelings on that one, one way or the other. Maybe a bit disappointed by this whole "his old soul is dead" business, but I can see it becoming a good hook for a further plot-line. And well, he's an A-hole for denouncing Leona, but ok, why not. As I said, no strong feelings.

But on Leona, I have mixed feelings. On one hand, the new write-ups are much more detailed, fleshed-out than before, probably a bit less clichéd too, and that's great. On the other hand, Leona was the compassionate and fierce warrior that arose to fight the zealous tenets of her own Rakkor tribe. Now, the Rakkor are better, but she is the zealot herself among the Solari (at least in the beginning), and I find the story of the "golden boy" less striking than her old Judgment piece: in the old piece, she had to actively go against customs and stand out for what she believed was right. In the new one, she was trained to fight warriors and monsters, so when she sees a young scared boy, as a decent human being she helps him. Much less heroic, if you ask me.

So... good job on the write-ups, they are great, but not sure I really like the new direction taken with Leona's lore.

Thank you :)

I'm rather disappointed with the new Leona lore.  In the old lore, she was selfless and compassionate - the flaws in her character were more aligned with being too compassionate and perhaps lacking the will to kill.  Now, that's all gone.  There's nothing that makes her stand out.

I know that (one of) the stated goal(s) of the lore rewrites is to keep what's core to the character, and that that's not always easy because people disagree on what that is.  But I'm honestly confused as to what parts of her character were (intended to be) kept.  Her old lore was almost entirely centred around protecting the weak, and that doesn't appear at all.  The incident with the golden boy reads more as enchantment than mercy.  Even if it's mercy, it doesn't give any sense that mercy is part of her character.  If you read it as mercy, it's more of 'that one time Leona failed in her duty'.

The second part of her lore doesn't add that either.  She's not really protecting people at cost to herself, but merely because they are more or less under her authority.

On the other hand, I like the Diana and Pantheon lore - it definitely makes Diana in particular a much deeper character, and it gives a much better view of Mount Targon overall.

EDIT: Oh, and the splash pictures are weirdly stretched.

An interesting point that I liked, not really related to this point, is that their skin became purple because it was exposed to the atmosphere of Runeterra. This actually makes sense from a biological stand point as them having an adverse reaction to a new world, but I also like the detail about them being pale and white; the Void is lightless, and so the creatures there need no colour on their bodies.

It is terribly interesting, because as the transformation occurs, it suggests the creatures are in pain, but once the shift is complete they don't seem irritated in the slightest. Could it be they adapt to Runeterra, like a callus that forms to strengthen the skin?

Potentially. It depends on how the Void and Runeterra interact. Runeterra and other planes of existence seem to work via portals and the blending of realities, where as for the Void it's like they aren't in sync, and the process for transitioning over is flawed. Perhaps these were planes that didn't intersect at one point, but were made to by interference (Icathia anyone? Or maybe something older?), and so the bleeding over is literally just because the realities aren't meant to have met and the reaction hurts both sides.

Makes me wonder what the Void side of things is like and how that affects that plane.
